details.name: DNA Methylation
details.description: DNA methylation is an epigenetic mechanism that involves the addition of a methyl group to DNA, typically at cytosine residues, and is often used as a biomarker for cancer diagnosis and risk assessment.
details.findings: DNA methylation data obtained with EPIC array in this study are publicly available at the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) repository with the Accession Number GSE220096.

details.name: IgA
details.description: Immunoglobulin A (IgA) is an antibody that plays a crucial role in the immune function of mucous membranes.
details.findings: IgA levels were measured and found to have low correlation with certain disease states.
details.notes: Correlation coefficient for IgA was mentioned as R=0.28.

details.name: Hemoglobin
details.description: Hemoglobin is a protein responsible for transporting oxygen in the blood.
details.findings: Hemoglobin levels were analyzed and showed a correlation with disease severity.

details.name: Albumin
details.description: Albumin is a protein made by the liver that helps keep fluid in the bloodstream.
details.findings: Albumin levels were found to be significantly different between healthy and diseased individuals.

details.name: Alpha-1-antitrypsin
details.description: Alpha-1-antitrypsin is a protein that protects the lungs from the damaging effects of inflammation.
details.findings: Alpha-1-antitrypsin levels were elevated in patients with certain inflammatory conditions.

details.name: Haptoglobin
details.description: Haptoglobin is a protein that binds to free hemoglobin in the blood.
details.findings: Haptoglobin levels were increased in patients with active inflammation.

details.name: Transferrin
details.description: Transferrin is a protein that transports iron in the blood.
details.findings: Transferrin levels were decreased in patients with chronic inflammation.

details.name: C-Reactive Protein (CRP)
details.description: C-Reactive Protein is an acute phase reactant produced by the liver in response to inflammation.
details.findings: C-reactive protein levels were elevated in patients with active inflammation.
details.notes: Generic knowledge only: Elevated CRP levels are associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer.

details.name: miR-126
details.description: A microRNA involved in various biological processes including angiogenesis and immune response.
details.findings: miR-126 has shown predictive data for early CRC stages.
details.notes: Part of a CEx-miRNAs panel for early CRC diagnosis

knowledge.subject: miR-126
knowledge.object: predictive data for early CRC stages

details.name: miR-1290
details.description: A microRNA that plays a role in cancer progression and metastasis.
details.findings: miR-1290 has shown predictive data for early CRC stages.
details.notes: Part of a CEx-miRNAs panel for early CRC diagnosis

knowledge.subject: miR-1290
knowledge.object: predictive data for early CRC stages

details.name: miR-23a
details.description: A microRNA involved in the regulation of cell growth, apoptosis, and differentiation.
details.findings: miR-23a has shown predictive data for early CRC stages.
details.notes: Part of a CEx-miRNAs panel for early CRC diagnosis

knowledge.subject: miR-23a
knowledge.object: predictive data for early CRC stages

details.name: miR-940
details.description: A microRNA that regulates cell proliferation and migration.
details.findings: miR-940 has shown predictive data for early CRC stages.
details.notes: Part of a CEx-miRNAs panel for early CRC diagnosis

knowledge.subject: miR-940
knowledge.object: predictive data for early CRC stages

details.name: BMAL1
details.description: A core component of the circadian clock that regulates cell proliferation and metabolism.
details.findings: BMAL1 suppresses tumor growth in colorectal cancer by regulating stemness and chemoresistance.

details.name: MSI
details.description: Microsatellite instability is a condition that affects DNA repair, leading to errors in microsatellite regions.
details.findings: MSI status is associated with prognosis and response to immunotherapy in colorectal cancer.

details.name: PD-L1
details.description: Programmed death-ligand 1 is a protein that plays a major role in suppressing the immune system.
details.findings: PD-L1 expression is a predictive biomarker for response to immunotherapy in colorectal cancer.

details.name: KRAS
details.description: A gene that is often mutated in colorectal cancer and plays a role in cell signaling and growth.
details.findings: KRAS mutations are associated with resistance to EGFR inhibitors in colorectal cancer.

details.name: BRAF
details.description: A gene involved in cell signaling and growth, often mutated in colorectal cancer.
details.findings: BRAF V600E mutations are associated with poor prognosis in colorectal cancer.

details.name: CTNNB1
details.description: A gene encoding beta-catenin, a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway.
details.findings: CTNNB1 mutations are associated with activation of the Wnt signaling pathway in colorectal cancer.

knowledge.subject: CTNNB1
knowledge.object: activation of the Wnt signaling pathway

details.name: PIK3CA
details.description: A gene encoding a subunit of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase, involved in cell growth and survival.
details.findings: PIK3CA mutations are associated with resistance to anti-EGFR therapy in colorectal cancer.

details.name: TP53
details.description: A tumor suppressor gene involved in DNA repair, cell cycle arrest, and apoptosis.
details.findings: TP53 mutations are common in colorectal cancer and associated with poor prognosis.

details.name: Ki-67
details.description: A protein associated with cell proliferation and is used as a marker for cancer progression.
details.findings: The article discusses the use of Ki-67 in immunohistochemical staining to assess cell proliferation in cancer research.

knowledge.subject: Ki-67
knowledge.object: assessing cell proliferation in cancer research

details.name: Caspase-3
details.description: An enzyme that plays a key role in apoptosis and is often studied in the context of cancer treatment response.
details.findings: The article mentions Caspase-3 in the context of studying apoptosis in cancer cells.

details.name: E-cadherin
details.description: A protein crucial for cell adhesion and is often downregulated in various types of cancer, indicating tumor progression.
details.findings: The article discusses E-cadherin expression levels in the context of cancer research.

details.name: CD44
details.description: A cell-surface glycoprotein involved in cell–cell interactions, adhesion, and migration, often used as a marker for cancer stem cells.
details.notes: Generic knowledge only: CD44 is commonly associated with colorectal cancer progression and metastasis.

details.name: Guanylate Cyclase-C
details.description: A transmembrane receptor that plays a role in the regulation of fluid and electrolyte balance in the intestinal epithelium.
details.findings: Guanylate Cyclase-C immunohistochemistry data was performed and interpreted as part of the study.

details.name: Chimeric Antigen Receptor
details.description: An engineered receptor that allows T cells to recognize and bind to specific antigens on cancer cells.
details.findings: The study involved quality control and testing of the product for the chimeric antigen receptor.

details.name: hCRISPRs
details.description: Human CRISPR-associated RNAs (hCRISPRs) are genetic elements involved in the transcriptional and diagnostic processes.
details.findings: The study aimed to detect and validate hCRISPRs for use in diagnostics, particularly focusing on their role in cancer diagnosis.

details.name: MiTranscriptome datasets
details.description: MiTranscriptome datasets are comprehensive collections of RNA sequences used to analyze and organize transcriptomic data.
details.findings: The MiTranscriptome datasets were analyzed and organized to provide insights into cancer diagnostics.

details.name: NGS-ProToCol samples
details.description: Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) ProToCol samples are used for genome sequencing and analysis in cancer research.
details.findings: The NGS-ProToCol samples were sequenced, analyzed, and provided to understand their role in cancer diagnosis.

details.name: RT-qPCR analyses
details.description: Real-Time Quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR) is a technique used to quantify gene expression levels, which can be indicative of disease states including cancer.
details.findings: RT-qPCR analyses were designed and performed to understand their role in cancer diagnostics.

details.name: SHERLOCK and DETECTR technologies
details.description: Specific High-Sensitivity Enzymatic Reporter UnLOCKing (SHERLOCK) and DNA Endonuclease Targeted CRISPR Trans Reporter (DETECTR) are diagnostic tools used for detecting specific genetic sequences, including those related to cancer.
details.findings: The SHERLOCK and DETECTR technologies were tested, optimized, and run to understand their role in cancer diagnosis.

details.name: Generic Cancer Biomarker
details.description: A generic biomarker related to colorectal cancer, used for early detection and diagnosis.
details.notes: This is a placeholder for a generic knowledge about colorectal cancer as no specific findings were mentioned in the article.

details.name: Hexanal
details.description: A six-carbon aldehyde that can be produced by lipid peroxidation in the body.
details.findings: Hexanal has been found to be a potential biomarker for colorectal cancer and inflammatory bowel disease.

details.name: Acetone
details.description: A simple ketone that is a byproduct of fat metabolism and can be excreted in the breath.
details.findings: Acetone levels in breath can change due to activities like exercising or fasting, making it an unreliable cancer biomarker despite its abnormal fruity odor.

details.name: Hexanoyl-CoA
details.description: An intermediate in fatty acid metabolism, particularly relevant to lipid peroxidation processes.
details.notes: Generic knowledge only. Hexanoyl-CoA has been generically associated with colorectal cancer.

details.name: 4-Heptanone
details.description: An organic compound that is a ketone, often used in flavor and fragrance industries.
details.notes: The origin of 4-heptanone is unclear and it is not recommended for use as a biomarker.

details.name: Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs)
details.description: Organic compounds produced by gut bacteria during fermentation of dietary fiber.
details.notes: Generic knowledge only. SCFAs have been generically associated with colorectal cancer risk.

details.name: Fusobacterium nucleatum
details.description: A species of bacteria associated with various infections and inflammations, including periodontal disease.
details.findings: Fusobacterium nucleatum was found to be significantly enriched in colorectal cancer patients compared to healthy controls.

details.name: Clostridium symbiosum
details.description: A species of bacteria found in the human gut microbiota.
details.findings: Clostridium symbiosum was identified as a potential biomarker for colorectal cancer risk assessment.

details.name: Bacteroides fragilis
details.description: A common gut bacterium that can produce a toxin linked to inflammation and cancer.
details.findings: The presence of Bacteroides fragilis was correlated with increased inflammation in colorectal cancer patients.

details.name: Escherichia coli
details.description: A species of bacteria commonly found in the lower intestine, some strains of which can cause disease.
details.findings: Certain strains of Escherichia coli were detected more frequently in patients with colorectal cancer compared to healthy individuals.

details.name: Streptococcus gallolyticus
details.description: A bacterium associated with various infections and inflammations, including endocarditis.
details.findings: The presence of Streptococcus gallolyticus was found to be a significant indicator of colorectal cancer risk.

details.name: Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs)
details.description: Gaseous metabolites produced by cells that can be detected in the breath and are associated with various diseases, including cancer.
details.findings: The study demonstrated that VOCs in the breath-print of CRC patients differ from those without the disease.
details.notes: Further chemical analysis is needed to understand the elevation and decrease of different VOCs in CRC patients.

details.name: Fecal Immunochemical Test (FIT)
details.description: A non-invasive test that detects hidden blood in the stool, which can be a sign of colorectal cancer.
details.findings: Generic knowledge only
details.notes: This biomarker is not explicitly discussed in the article and this is generic knowledge only.

details.name: T-antigen
details.description: The T-antigen (Thomsen-Friedenreich antigen) is a disaccharide found on the surface of cells, often associated with cancer and inflammation.
details.findings: Abnormal immature glycan signatures, including the presence of T-antigen, were observed in stool samples from individuals with more aggressive non-cancerous lesions and cancer, but not in healthy tissues.

knowledge.subject: T-antigen
knowledge.object: stool samples from individuals with more aggressive non-cancerous lesions and cancer

mistral-large/ZfOe_.prompt_template:
[BEGIN ARTICLE]:<content></content>
[END ARTICLE]

[INSTRUCTIONS]
Generate list of biomarkers that are mentioned as methods, result or discussion in the article and relates to disease, inflamation or specifically cancer diagnosis or risc. 
List only biomarkers that some findings are in the article. If no findings is in the article about such biomarker, don't include it in list.
For each such biomarker extract name, type, description, notes and findings.
For findings, put the findings about the biomarker that are either result or discussed in the article.
For description, put general description of the biomarker, that description do not need to be in the article but should be descriptive.
For notes, put general notes about biomarker that are explicitly noted in the article besides findings. 
For each finding generate a formal knowledge triplet separated to "subject","predicate","object" where "subject" is biomarker, "predicate" is verb from finding and "object" is an object from the finding.
If there is no knowledge in the article, generate single generic knowledge that relates to colorectal cancer and leave in the notes that it is generic knowledge only.
Return the response in strict JSON format with the following structure:

[
  { "name": "biomarker name","type":"biomarker type","description":"biomarker description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker or empty string", "knowledge":[{"subject":"repeated biomarker name","predicate":"some predicate from findings of biomarker","object":"object that relates via predicate to the biomarker" }],
  { "name": "biomarker2 name","type":"biomarker2 type","description":"biomarker2 description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker2 in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker2 or empty string", "knowledge":[{"subject":"repeated biomarker2 name","predicate":"some predicate from findings of  biomarker2","object":"object that relates via predicate to the biomarker2" }] }
] 

Ensure there is no additional explanation, only return valid JSON.
